para.paratext: An expert witness may be cross-examined about his credentials and have his specialized knowledge tested,[1] even though he has been qualified as an expert by the court. For example, a handwriting expert may be asked on cross-examination to identify handwriting.[2] He may be examined as to his testimony in other cases, including for which parties he usually testifies.[3] His credibility may be examined, and it is proper to ask what he was being paid “to come here and testify.”[4]
A real estate appraiser may be cross-examined as to the methodology by which value to a property was assigned.[5]

Under Georgia law, an expert witness can be cross-examined by reference to a proven standard treatise in the field of the expert's special knowledge.[6] The cross-examiner may establish the authoritative status of material used through questioning the witness, but the witness does not have to use the words “standard” or “authoritative.”[7] Such books are not, however, admissible in evidence to prove the opinions of the authors contained in them.[8]

In Mize v. State,[9] the Georgia Supreme Court held that an expert witness could be cross-examined on statements from a particular text after the expert had testified he was familiar with the text and had studied under editors of the text and that the text was accepted as one of the many books in the field.

In Pound v. Medney,[10] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that an expert witness may be cross-examined on an article contained in the Journal of the American Medical Association which was published two years after the incident. The expert had not stated the particular article was authoritative, but had testified that the Journal of the American Medical Association was “one of the best” sources of medical information.

Citing Mize and Pound, the Georgia Court of Appeals in Packer v. Gill[11] upheld the trial court's ruling that expert witnesses could be cross-examined based upon statements contained in a particular medical textbook that the experts used in their practices and was used in medical schools.
In Wooten v. Dept. of Human Resources,[12] the court held that “an expert should not be permitted to block cross-examination by refusing to concede that a text or treatise is authoritative.”[13]

Many jurisdictions allow the authoritative status of a textbook to be established through witnesses other than the witness under cross-examination.[14] Fed. R. Evid. 803(18) and O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(18) take this approach.

An expert or lay witness may be cross-examined on any matter relevant to any issue in the proceeding.[15] This differs from the federal rules, which limit cross-examination to matters addressed during direct examination and issues of credibility.[16]
Richards v. Harpe, 42 Ga. App. 123, 155 S.E. 85 (1930).

As a matter of first impression in Georgia, it was held in Dimambro Northend Associates v. Williams, 169 Ga. App. 219, 312 S.E.2d 386 (1983), that a party has the right to cross-examine the opposing party's expert on the limited question of his qualifications before the witness is qualified as an expert and permitted to state his opinion. However, in this case the error in not permitting such cross-examination was not prejudicial.

In Delaware v. Fensterer, 474 U.S. 15, 106 S. Ct. 292, 88 L. Ed. 2d 15, 18 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 945 (1985), the expert witness could not remember the theory on which he had based his opinion. The Court held that this went only to the weight of his opinion and did not preclude adequate cross-examination so as to violate the confrontation or due process clauses.
Travelers' Ins. Co. v. Sheppard, 85 Ga. 751, 12 S.E. 18 (1890).
Harrison v. Regents of University System of Georgia, 99 Ga. App. 762, 109 S.E.2d 854 (1959); Sutton v. State Highway Dept., 103 Ga. App. 29, 118 S.E.2d 285 (1961).

Department of Transp. v. Lowery, 163 Ga. App. 114, 291 S.E.2d 573 (1982), held that an expert witness could be asked on cross-examination how often he had testified in other condemnation cases. He was referred to as a “professional witness.”

In Thomas v. Newnan Hosp., 185 Ga. App. 764, 365 S.E.2d 859 (1988), the plaintiff could not ask the defendant's expert if he was the “regular” expert for defendant's insurer as this would improperly show liability insurance.
Rogers v. Black, 121 Ga. App. 299, 173 S.E.2d 431 (1970); Andrews v. Major, 180 Ga. App. 393, 349 S.E.2d 225 (1986).
Oglethorpe Power Corp. v. Estate of Forrister, 332 Ga. App. 693, 774 S.E.2d 755 (2015).

To the extent called to the attention of an expert witness upon cross-examination, statements contained in published treatises, periodicals, or pamphlets, whether published electronically or in print, on a subject of history, medicine, or other science or art, established as a reliable authority by the testimony or admission of the witness, by other expert testimony, or by judicial notice. If admitted, the statements may be used for cross-examination of an expert witness and read into evidence but shall not be received as exhibits.

See also Brannen v. Prince, 204 Ga. App. 866, 421 S.E.2d 76 (1992) (overruled on other grounds by, Gillis v. City of Waycross, 247 Ga. App. 119, 543 S.E.2d 423 (2000)) and (overruled on other grounds by, Smith v. Finch, 285 Ga. 709, 681 S.E.2d 147 (2009)).
Packer v. Gill, 193 Ga. App. 388, 388 S.E.2d 338 (1989).
Wooten v. Department of Human Resources, 152 Ga. App. 304, 262 S.E.2d 583 (1979).
Dabroe v. Rhodes Co., 64 Wash. 2d 431, 392 P.2d 317 (1964).

McCormack v. Lindberg, 352 N.W.2d 30 (Minn. Ct. App. 1984); Wolak v. Walczak, 125 Mich. App. 271, 335, 335 N.W.2d 908 (1983); Foster v. McKeesport Hospital, 260 Pa. Super. 485, 394 A.2d 1031 (1978); Kansas City v. Dugan, 524 S.W.2d 194 (Mo. Ct. App. 1975); Ravenis v. Detroit General Hospital, 63 Mich. App. 79, 234 N.W.2d 411 (1975); Iverson v. Lancaster, 158 N.W.2d 507 (N.D. 1968); William Cameron Co. v. Downing, 147 S.W.2d 963 (Tex. Civ. App. El Paso 1941); People v. Behnke, 41 Ill. App. 3d 276, 353 N.E.2d 684 (5th Dist. 1976).
R.C. Acres, Inc. v. Cambridge Faire Properties, LLC, 331 Ga. App. 762, 771 S.E.2d 444 (2015).
